creator: brown2@reflexe.fr
text:
After a WAR file is deployed and unpacked by Tomcat, irrespective of the value 
of the "unpackWARs" attribute in server.xml, replacing the WAR file with a 
newer version (an "upgrade") does nothing, because a newer version of the WAR
file is ignored if any previous version has already been unpacked (until the
unpacked files are deleted).  If the WAR file is updated, it's *probably*
safe to assume that this was done voluntarily, and so any previous unpacked
version should be removed then replaced.

This was discussed on the tomcat-dev mailing list on 22nd January 2002.

I came across his missbehaviur and found it most confuesing. Even if a war is
updated and tomcat restarted is still continues to run the old application.
creator: boris@ipunplugged.com

text:
The discussion was in Jan 2003 rather than 2002. See 
http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=tomcat-dev&m=104325159107245&w=2

Having reviewed the discussion and this bug, I think this is an enhancement 
request.
creator: markt@apache.org
markt@apache.org
text: This was fixed in Remy'e re-write of the deployer code in 5.5.x. An updated WAR file will now get deployed even if the old unpacked directory is present providing Tomcat is running when the WAR is replaced. If Tomcat is not running, then the unpacked WAR still needs to be removed.
